bioghist.p: William, Lord Nelson (1757-1835), was the elder brother and heir of Horatio of Nelson. He was ordained in 1781 and served very briefly under his brother as chaplain to his command, the frigate Boreas (1784-1786). The seagoing life did not suit him, and he returned to Norfolk where he married and eventually settled in Hilborough in Norfolk. In 1802 Nelson was awarded a doctorate of divinity from the University of Cambridge, and in 1803 he received the same degree from Oxford. Later the same year, he was appointed a prebendary of Canterbury. Upon Horatio Nelson's death in 1805, William inherited the Duchy of Bronte (which had been awarded to Horatio by the King of the Two Sicilies in 1799), along with the title of Baron Nelson of the Nile, and an annual pension of £5000. Nelson died in London on 28 February 1835. His daughter, who had married Baron Bridport in 1810, now succeeded to the Sicilian title of Duchess of Bronte. Lady Bridport's inheritance was compromised by Horatio’s will endorsing the rival claims of his sisters, Susannah Bolton and Catherine Matcham, who both had sons. Litigation between the two sides of the family continued for roughly ten years after the death of William Nelson. J. Hutchinson was one of William Nelson's solicitors; W. Bryant Barrett was agent for the Duchy of Bronte. After Barrett's death, his widow Martha Barrett took over supervision of the estate for a period of time. After this, A. Nelson Hood acted as agent for the Duchy.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of papers mainly relating to estates of Nelson's Dukedom of Bronte in Sicily. Materials include: manuscript letters and copies of letters, legal papers, drafts and final versions of wills, and codicils (1806 to 1904). The collection also includes several other documents relating to the Lord Nelson trust, and a 1739 indenture between Thomas Fergison and his wife Mary, who was the heir of both Samuel Pitt and William Pitt.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
